segments.text: Long day. Let me just record some thoughts before I head home.
The situation with Tony this morning... that was tough. I hated having to come down on him like that.
But he was wrong. You can't yell at people in front of their crews, no matter how frustrated you are.
The hard part is, I get it. I've been there. Twenty years ago I probably would've done the same thing.
But I've learned that leadership isn't about being the toughest guy on the site. It's about building teams that respect each other.
Tony's a good project manager. He cares about the work. That's why he lost his temper - because he gives a damn.
I just need to help him channel that energy into constructive leadership instead of... whatever that was yesterday.
And the plumbing contractor - I need to call them tomorrow. Third late arrival is a pattern. We can't tolerate that.
But I also can't blow up the relationship. Finding good subs right now is nearly impossible with this labor shortage.
So I'll be firm but fair. Give them one chance to fix it. If it happens again, we find someone else.
On the positive side, financials look good. If we get Riverside, we'll have our best year ever.
Patricia seemed confident at dinner. I think we have a real shot at this.
Twelve point eight million. That would put us at nearly 75 million in backlog. We'd need to hire at least three more people.
Growing pains. Good problems to have, but still problems.
I wonder sometimes if I'm getting too old for this. Running a construction company is exhausting.
But then I walk a site and see something we built, and I remember why I love it.
Alright, enough reflection. Time to go home and not think about work for a few hours.

environment.background_sounds: quiet evening office, distant cleaning crew, occasional car outside
